I believe it to bt1 generally true that men and women who have the spirit, to embark on the hazards of migration are prepared to make the be.=t of the opportunities they find in the country to which they go. Therefore, we may expect those who come to Australia to build their own homes, and to play their full part in developing the country's resources. In 1923, in

Greater .Melbourne alone, no fewer than 10,000 homes were built, and as many more were built in the following year. Now, the Government is talking of a housing policy which aims at providing 20,000 homes a year throughout the whole of Australia, when private enterprise in one city alone provided more than that number in the space of two years. I decry the Government's craven approach to the problem of immigration. Let us consider what has been done in regard to the rehabilitation of ex-members of the forces, and what remains to be done. In comparison, the absorption of 70,000 migrants a year, beginning in two year's time, appears to be a mere trifle. There are no fewer than 600,000 service men and women to be absorbed, and about 700,000 civilians engaged in war occupations. Their absorption represents a tremendous undertaking, but we are not dismayed. "We have no doubt that it can be done. Already, 300,000 persons formerly in the services have been absorbed into civil life. If the Government is concerned about finding employment for migrants during the ^period immediately after their arrival, I recommend that it consider what was achieved in the past under the nomination system under which immigrants were nominated by people already in Australia who were prepared, if necessary, to find jobs for them or to support them until they found jobs for themselves. In this way, a large number of migrants could be absorbed without imposing an undue strain on the economy of the nation. I suggest that the system should not be confined to immigrants from Great Britain. There are people in Australia of foreign extraction with friends in European countries who may be willing to migrate to Australia. There are also people here of British descent who know others in European countries whom they might be prepared to nominate.

If we are to induce immigrants to come here in large numbers we must make conditions attractive. Now that the war ' is over there will be competition for such migrants as are prepared to leave Europe. All the dominions will be seeking immigrants, and probably the South American countries and some of the African States as well. In discussions on this subject a good deal of emphasis has been laid by. honorable members opposite on measures designed to provide social security. Most of the more highly developed countries, including Great Britain, have social security schemes of their own, although their value has probably been reduced during the war because of inflation. Usually, the schemes are on a contributory basis. The Overseas Settlement Board discussed this problem in 1938, and recommended that in the dominions where social security schemes were established, or were being developed, there should be an assurance of reciprocity for the benefit of immigrants. I understand, from a reply given by the Minister for Immigration to-day to the honorable member for New England (Mr. Abbott), that the Government proposes to introduce such a scheme here. However, important as that may be to the prospective migrant, I believe that he will be far more interested in opportunity than in social security, as we understand the phrase in this country. He will be more concerned to find conditions under which he may, by his own efforts, gain an adequate reward for his energy, enterprise and resource. In that lugard, we are under a heavy handicap in Australia at the present time. If he is sufficiently inquisitive the prospective migrant will find that Australia is still the most heavily taxed country in the English-speaking world, and, judging by recent ministerial statements, it is likely to remain so for a considerable time. If we are to attract migrants we must offer conditions which will enable them to better themselves and their families.

I turn now to another reference in the Minister's speech in which he indicated a possible reluctance on the part of the Government of Great Britain to permit substantial numbers of people to come to Australia. The Minister based that fear on the ground that Great Britain has its own serious population problem. It is typical of British people and those who speak for them in their governments, that although this aspect is clearly recognized, it has not been allowed to dissuade them from pursuing a progressive policy of migration for their own people. In this connexion I refer first to the following statement in the report of the Oversea Settlement Board of May, 1938 : -

quote.para: It can no longer bc assumed as axiomatic that the migration of large numbers of persons from the United Kingdom to the Dominions is in the interests of the United Kingdom, if those interests could be considered in isolation from those of the Dominions. Even now, it is only from the point of view of the strengthening of the Empire as a whole that the encouragement of migration from the United Kingdom can be justified. The resumption of migration on a large scale could, unless the present population trends are checked, diminish still further the future population of the United Kingdom. In our opinion, however, 110 merely theoretical calculation of the consequences of population movements should be allowed to affect migration policy.

speech.para: Then we have the more recent statement made in the House of Lords on the 24th May, 1944, by Viscount Cranborne. the Secretary of State for Dominion Affairs. His statement is quoted in an appendix to the Minister'3 statement. Viscount Cranborne said-

quote.para: Wc have made it abundantly clear that, notwithstanding the fact that our own population in these islands is tending, perhaps, rather to decrease than to increase, yet, on .broad Imperial grounds we do feel that we should encourage and assist, as far as is practicable, i inter-Imperial migration if that is desired by the Dominion Governments themselves; and, of course, on the assumption - the very necessary assumption - that those Governments of the other Empire countries are prepared to make their own contribution to schemes of assisted migration.

speech.para: And so we find that despite their- own serious population problem, successive Governments in Great Britain have consistently adhered to the view that it is in the best interests of the Empire as a whole that people who desire to migrateto the- Dominions, which obviously areundeveloped and underpopulated, should be given Government encouragement todo so.

I come now to an important phase of this subject which the Minister developed in his statement, namely the attitude of the Australian people to immigrants. The Minister rightly emphasized theneed for.e. change of attitude on the part of many people in this country if the immigrant is to feel welcome, and if asthe result of the friendly atmosphere and hospitable treatment .meted out by Australian citizens he is to be encouraged in turn to recommend' his friends- and' relatives to come to this, country.. I find! lt somewhat difficult to understand this curiously intolerant attitude to people of other countries who settle here. Possibly it is due to the fact that hitherto we have been a homogeneous people. We are still 98 per cent. British, and 87 per cent, of our people were born in Australia. Our population is nearly 100 per cent, of the white race. Perhaps, due to these circumstances, there has developed amongst an uncomfortably large proportion of our people, an hostility to foreigners and even to British migrants who come here. There is no need to go into detail, but it is within our experience that that atmosphere has existed in the past and does exist to-day. In some quarters it is probably stronger to-day than ever. If migrants from certain areas in Europe tend to settle in this country in communities of their own nationality, I do not think that we can altogether disclaim all responsibility for that state of affairs. Naturally if we do not absorb them into our community in a congenial way they will turn to the company of people with the same national affiliations, habits, and ideas as their own; but that that is not necessarily the case the experience of the United States of America has shown. That country has been able to absorb very large numbers of the people of all other countries. It has not. merely absorbed them, but, as my leader pointed out earlier, the events of the war have revealed a unity on the part of the American people, on the field of battle and in factories and industry generally, which enabled that country to produce such remarkable national and industrial results. The proportion of people of alien stock in this country and our alien problems of Australia are insignificant contrasted with those of other countries.

talk.start.para: - They are non-existent.

- For that reason, it is all the more remarkable to find so many people in this country displaying hostility, intolerance, and bitterness to people from other lands. ' I hope that the plans which the Government has indicated for creating a different state of mind on the Dart of those Australians who react in this way, will prove successful. I hope, too, that we shall be able to display that tolerance which is a typical characteristic of the British race to those people who hazard their future in coming to our shores, and who, if accepted in the community, can add so much to our national progress and production.

speech.para: It is not necessary at this stage to go into details, or to dwell unduly on points which other speakers have already covered, and so, I come back to the point which I made earlier, and ask the Government not to be too fearful in this matter. I feel that we are at a stage in our national history when an opportunity which is only rarely given to a country is presented to us. The world is disturbed and will take years to settle down. People in European countries particularly have had their homes and industries destroyed. They have developed bitternesses, one against the other, because of factional disagreements as the result of war pressures borne upon them. Because so many people in all parts of the world will be looking to a future in which they will be able to rebuild their lives, homes and industries, an opportunity exists that Australia should not lose. We should be able to-day to attract people that through the years of insecurity have longed for a country where they would not be subjected to the same hazards and destruction as they have experienced twice in a lifetime in their own lands. So I ask the Government to strike while the iron is hot. I have every confidence that once migrants come to Australia, with the statesmanship that I hope exists in this chamber, we shall be able to provide opportunities for their absorption. I have no doubt that if Ave can cope successfully with the very much greater problem of rehabilitating hundreds of thousands of our own men and women, we shall be able to cope successfully with the absorption of about 70,000 immigrants a year. Do not let the fears, particularly of industrial workers expressed through their trade union representatives, weigh unduly because to-day is the day of opportunity for Australia as far as immigration is concerned. If We neglect the opportunity it may not occur again in our lifetime.

talk.start.para: - The position in regard to international air services is that neither the Convention on International Civil Aviation nor the Interim Agreement on International Civil Aviation drawn up at Chicago last December provides any rights for regular international air services to traverse or land in other countries. The rights for regular international air services are covered in two supplementary agreements, namely, the International Air Services Transit Agreement and the International Air Transport Agreement. The former grants to other States party to the agreement the rights of transit and landing for non-traffic purposes. The Transport Agreement confers rights for the air services to pick up and set down passengers. answer.para: The Commonwealth Government is now party to the Interim Agreement and action is in hand to make Australia party also to the Transit Agreement. As indicated previously, neither of these agreements authorizes international air services to pick up or set down passengers in Australia. If and when any bilateral agreement is being negotiated to permit foreign air services to carry passengers into or from Australia, the question whether such service will he permitted to carry local traffic between points in Australia will have to be considered in light of the circumstances then applying. It is realized that should the Australian Government decide to reserve this right of cabotage the other government concerned might do likewise and that possibility will have to be taken into consideration by the Government before reaching its decision.
